PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  required  to  undertake  due 
diligence to (i) assess improvements required to urban services in Trincomalee Town, and (ii) 
identify strategic investments and actions to boost the region's economy. The second part of the 
PPTA will be undertaken through direct charges from the Urban Financing Partnership Facility 
(UFPF) and descriptions in this Appendix is limited to the first part alone. The PPTA will: 
 
(i)  Undertake  sector  preparatory  work,  define  the  scope  of  the  ensuing  project,  and 
undertake (a) technical feasibility assessment, (b) safeguards due diligence, and (c) 
financial and economic viability assessment of the ensuing project; 
(ii)  Undertake an assessment of strategic economic interventions and associated industrial 
development required to boost economic development in the Trincomalee Metropolitan 
Urban Development Area (TMUDA); 
(iii)  Assist  the  Ministry  of  Defense  and  Urban  Development  (MDUD)  and  Urban 
Development Authority (UDA) in undertaking advance contracting actions for the project 
and appoint the design and supervision consultants (DSC), possibly financed through 
the project design advance (PDA)1; and 
(iv)  Undertake  necessary  surveys  and  investigations  to  address  technical,  safeguards, 
financial and economic viability of the ensuing project. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities

through advance actions will undertake further detailing of identified interventions and develop 
detailed engineering designs, safeguards plans, and bidding documents.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

under  the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  (WFPF)  and  administered  by  ADB. 
Approximately $225,000 through direct charges from the Urban Environmental Infrastructure

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  Ten  individuals  comprising  3  international  consultants  and  7  national  consultants 
(providing 30 person-months of input) will be engaged to undertake the PPTA. Table A4.3 
summarizes the consulting services requirement for the individuals.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paragraphs 6 
to 15. 
 
  1.  Outline terms of reference for international consultants 
 
6.  Project Management Expert and Team Leader. The Team Leader will be an Engineer 
with minimum 20 years of experience in the infrastructure industry with a focus on urban 
services. She/he will (i) assist on advance contracting actions to appoint the DSC; (ii) coordinate 
technical feasibility assessment, safeguards assessment, and economic and financial viability

assessment; and (iii) assist on bidding document preparation and bid process management for 
identified advance procurement actions. All team members will report to the Team Leader. 
 
7.  Civil Engineer. The Civil Engineer will have minimum 20 years of experience in the 
water supply, sewerage and storm water drainage sectors. She/he will (i) draft the terms of 
reference for the DSC; (ii) undertake technical assessment and define the scope of the project; 
(iii)  undertake  quality  check  of  the  engineering  designs  undertaken  by  the  DSC  prior  to 
undertaking identified advance procurement actions; and (iv) review the specifications and 
functional guarantees of the bidding documents. She/he will draw support from the national Civil 
Engineer. 
 
8.  Procurement Specialist. The Procurement Specialist will hold a graduate degree in a 
major relevant discipline (e.g., Procurement, Engineering, Law, Management or Business) and 
preferably have five years experience in procurement practices internationally, with background 
in the implementation of development projects. She/he will oversee the work of the national 
specialist and undertake procurement capacity assessment of the EA and IA, and identify 
capacity building measures for project implementation.  
 
  2.  Outline terms of reference for national consultants 
 
9.  Financial Management Specialist. The Financial Management Specialist will have a 
background  in  accounting  and/or  financial  management  and/or  Masters  in  Business 
Administration,  preferably  a  qualified  professional  accountant,  with  extensive  knowledge  of 
working with service utilities – power, telecom or water for a minimum 10 years. She/he will (i) 
undertake a governance and financial management assessment of UDA and TUC; (ii) prepare a 
financial model to simulate cash flows for urban services; (iii) suggest a tariff structure for urban 
services based on the modeling; (iv) undertake a financial viability assessment of the proposed 
project; (v) design funds flow and disbursement mechanisms for the ensuing project; and (vi) 
identify  capacity  building  measures  on  financial  management  and  ADB  disbursement 
procedures.  
 
10.  Economist. The Economist will have a background of having undertaken economic 
analysis for infrastructure projects comprising roads, urban transport, power, telecom and water 
for a minimum 10 years. She/he will (i) undertake economic viability analysis of the proposed 
project drawing from existing data and willingness to pay studies, and (ii) suggest a tariff 
structure along with the Financial Management Specialist. 
 
11.  Civil Engineer. The Civil Engineer will have a minimum experience of 15 years and 
support the international Civil Engineer in her/his activities. 
 
12.  Environmental Specialist. The Environmental Specialist will have a background of 
having  undertaken  environmental  assessment  for  infrastructure  projects  comprising  roads, 
urban transport, power, telecom and water for a minimum 5 years. She/he will assess the UDA’s 
and  TUC’s  capacity  to  respond  to  ADB's  environmental  safeguard  requirements  in  the 
Safeguards  Policy  Statement  (2009),  safeguards  assessment  through  initial  environmental 
examination for the project, and develop an environmental management plan for identified 
interventions.  
 
13.  Resettlement Specialist. The Resettlement Specialist will have a background of having 
undertaken resettlement planning for infrastructure projects comprising roads, urban transport, 
power, telecom and water for a minimum 5 years. She/he will undertake assessing the UDA’s

and TUC’s capacity to respond to ADB's social safeguard requirements in the Safeguards 
Policy Statement (2009), involuntary resettlement assessment and prepare a resettlement plan 
for the project interventions as required.  
 
14.  Social Development and Gender Specialist. The Social Development and Gender 
Specialist will have a background of having undertaken poverty reduction and social impacts 
assessment, and gender assessment and action planning for a minimum 5 years. The Specialist 
will work closely with the social development team in the DSC to prepare the gender action plan 
(GAP) for the project. 
 
15.  Procurement Specialist. The Procurement Specialist will hold a graduate degree in a 
major relevant discipline (e.g., Procurement, Engineering, Law, Management or Business) and 
preferably have five years experience in procurement practices in Sri Lanka, with background in 
the implementation of development projects, whereby experience in the area of recruitment of 
consulting firms, civil works and good procurement by following international financial institution, 
preferable ADB procurement reviews/audits, country procurement assessments and national 
procurement reform programs will be a strong advantage. The Procurement Specialist will (i) 
assist on advance contracting actions to appoint the DSC; and (ii) undertake procurement 
capacity assessment of the EA and IA, and identify capacity building measures for project 
implementation.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The MDUD will be the PPTA’s executing agency. It will provide in-kind contributions in 
the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, and communication facilities 
for consultants. The proposed PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table 
A4.4. Consultants will be mobilized in a staggered manner with a focus on prioritizing the 
advance  actions  on:  (i)  recruiting  the  DSC,  and  (ii)  undertaking  requisite  surveys  and 
investigations.  Disbursement  under  the  PPTA  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended).
